replies.bodyText:
Personally I find nested ifs harder to read than an explicit list of priorities
This presents more like a checklist,
if val == null write null
if listValue != nul then return that.
Especially with things like trace entry/exit enabled it makes it easier to reasn where your code reaches and when it is early exiting.
If/elsiif isn't bad, but it leads to less maintainable code as it is added to, from my experience, not sure if other maintainers such as @ppatierno might have opinon on this.
Obviously it is just an issue of styling, but it can matter.

timeline.bodyText: In the ingress-specific property is called ingressClass shouldn't this be be preferredNodeportAddressType?
timeline.author: tombentley

replies.bodyText:
I called ingressClass that way because the field it changes is called like that and I do not think other things have any similar concept. On the other hand, I can for example imagine that preferredAddressType is in the future also used for load balancers to define whether a DNS name or an IP address should be preferred.
If I had to choose, I would probably tend to rename the ingressClass to class rather than the other way around. WDYT?
replies.author: scholzj

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, it's tricky. One of the hazards of using an object with properties which have to cope with the union of the different types. I think class would be a bit weird, because it would configure the ingressClass field you mentioned in the case of ingress and something else for another type so there wouldn't be a 1-to-1 correspondence. Not that there has to be, but it's helpful for people's mental model when there is. I think I would prefer what you already have over using class.
If load balancers gained a similar thing then having both preferredNodeportAddressType and preferredLoadBalancerAddressType would not be terrible. But I'm not wedded to the idea.
